tasks.name: Pilot Qualifications
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with airman and medical certificates including privileges, limitations, currency, and operating as pilot-in- command as a private pilot.

PA.I.A.K1.description: Certification requirements, recent flight experience, and recordkeeping.

PA.I.A.K3.description: Medical certificates: class, expiration, privileges, temporary disqualifications.

PA.I.A.K4.description: Documents required to exercise private pilot privileges.

PA.I.A.K5.description: Part 68 BasicMed privileges and limitations. Risk

PA.I.A.R2.description: Flying unfamiliar aircraft or operating with unfamiliar flight display systems and avionics.

PA.I.A.S1.description: Apply requirements to act as pilot-in-command (PIC) under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) in a scenario given by the evaluator.

tasks.name: Airworthiness Requirements
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with airworthiness requirements, including airplane certificates.

PA.I.B.K1.description: General airworthiness requirements and compliance for airplanes, including:
a. Location and expiration dates of required aircraft certificates
b. Required inspections and airplane logbook documentation
c. Airworthiness Directives and Special Airworthiness Information Bulletins
d. Purpose and procedure for obtaining a special flight permit

PA.I.B.K3.description: Equipment requirements for day and night VFR flight, including:
b. Using an approved Minimum Equipment List (MEL)
c. Kinds of Operation Equipment List (KOEL)
d. Required discrepancy records or placards

PA.I.B.K4.description: Standard and special airworthiness certificates and their associated operational limitations. Risk

PA.I.B.R1.description: Inoperative equipment discovered prior to flight.

PA.I.B.S1.description: Locate and describe airplane airworthiness and registration information.

PA.I.B.S2.description: Determine the airplane is airworthy in the scenario given by the evaluator.

PA.I.B.S3.description: Apply appropriate procedures for operating with inoperative equipment in the scenario given by the evaluator.

tasks.name: Weather Information
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with weather information for a flight under VFR.
note: If K2 is selected, the evaluator must assess the applicant’s knowledge of at least three sub-elements.
If K3 is selected, the evaluator must assess the applicant’s knowledge of at least three sub-elements.

PA.I.C.K1.description: Sources of weather data (e.g., National Weather Service, Flight Service) for flight planning purposes.

PA.I.C.K2.description: Acceptable weather products and resources required for preflight planning, current and forecast weather for departure, en route, and arrival phases of flight such as:
a. Airport Observations (METAR and SPECI) and Pilot Observations (PIREP)
b. Surface Analysis Chart, Ceiling and Visibility Chart (CVA)
e. Wind and Temperature Aloft Forecast (FB)
g. Inflight Aviation Weather Advisories including Airmen's Meteorological Information (AIRMET), Significant Meteorological Information (SIGMET), and Convective SIGMET

PA.I.C.K3.description: Meteorology applicable to the departure, en route, alternate, and destination under visual flight rules (VFR) in Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC), including expected climate and hazardous conditions such as:
b. Wind (e.g., windshear, mountain wave, factors affecting wind, etc.)
e. Weather system formation, including air masses and fronts
i. Icing and freezing level information
l. Obstructions to visibility (e.g., smoke, haze, volcanic ash, etc.)

PA.I.C.K4.description: Flight deck instrument displays of digital weather and aeronautical information. Risk

PA.I.C.R1.description: Making the go/no-go and continue/divert decisions, including:
a. Circumstances that would make diversion prudent
c. Hazardous weather conditions, including known or forecast icing or turbulence aloft

PA.I.C.R2.description: b. Aviation weather reports and forecasts

PA.I.C.S1.description: Use available aviation weather resources to obtain an adequate weather briefing.

PA.I.C.S2.description: Analyze the implications of at least three of the conditions listed in K3a through K3l, using actual weather or weather conditions provided by the evaluator.

PA.I.C.S3.description: Correlate weather information to make a go/no-go decision.

tasks.name: Cross-Country Flight Planning
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with cross-country flights and VFR flight planning.
note: Preparation, presentation, and explanation of a computer-generated flight plan is an acceptable option.

PA.I.D.K1.description: Route planning, including consideration of different classes and special use airspace (SUA) and selection of appropriate and available navigation/communication systems and facilities.
a. Use of an electronic flight bag (EFB), if used

PA.I.D.K2.description: Altitude selection accounting for terrain and obstacles, glide distance of airplane, VFR cruising altitudes, and effect of wind.

PA.I.D.K3.description: a. Time, climb and descent rates, course, distance, heading, true airspeed, and groundspeed
b. Estimated time of arrival, including conversion to universal coordinated time (UTC)

PA.I.D.K4.description: Elements of a VFR flight plan.

PA.I.D.K5.description: Procedures for filing, activating, and closing a VFR flight plan.

PA.I.D.R3.description: Environment (e.g., weather, airports, airspace, terrain, obstacles).

PA.I.D.R5.description: Limitations of air traffic control (ATC) services.

PA.I.D.R7.description: Use of an electronic flight bag (EFB), if used.

PA.I.D.S1.description: Prepare, present, and explain a cross-country flight plan assigned by the evaluator, including a risk analysis based on real-time weather, to the first fuel stop.

PA.I.D.S2.description: Apply pertinent information from appropriate and current aeronautical charts, Chart Supplements; Notices to Air Missions (NOTAMs) relative to airport, runway and taxiway closures; and other flight publications.

PA.I.D.S3.description: Create a navigation plan and simulate filing a VFR flight plan.

PA.I.D.S4.description: Recalculate fuel reserves based on a scenario provided by the evaluator.

PA.I.D.S5.description: Use an electronic flight bag (EFB), if applicable.

tasks.name: National Airspace System
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with National Airspace System (NAS) operations under VFR as a private pilot.

PA.I.E.K1.description: Airspace classes and associated requirements and limitations.

PA.I.E.K3.description: Special use airspace (SUA), special flight rules areas (SFRA), temporary flight restrictions (TFR), and other airspace areas.

PA.I.E.K4.description: Special visual flight rules (VFR) requirements. Risk

PA.I.E.R1.description: Various classes and types of airspace.

PA.I.E.S1.description: Identify and comply with the requirements for basic VFR weather minimums and flying in particular classes of airspace.

PA.I.E.S2.description: Correctly identify airspace and operate in accordance with associated communication and equipment requirements.

PA.I.E.S3.description: Identify the requirements for operating in SUA or within a TFR. Identify and comply with special air traffic rules (SATR) and SFRA operations, if applicable.

tasks.name: Performance and Limitations
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with operating an airplane safely within the parameters of its performance capabilities and limitations.

PA.I.F.K1.description: Elements related to performance and limitations by explaining the use of charts, tables, and data to determine performance.

PA.I.F.R1.description: Use of performance charts, tables, and data.

PA.I.F.R3.description: Possible differences between calculated performance and actual performance.

PA.I.F.S1.description: Compute the weight and balance, correct out-of-CG loading errors and determine if the weight and balance remains within limits during all phases of flight.

PA.I.F.S2.description: Use the appropriate airplane performance charts, tables, and data.

tasks.name: Operation of Systems
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with safe operation of systems on the airplane provided for the flight test.
note: If K1 is selected, the evaluator must assess the applicant's knowledge of at least three sub-elements.

PA.I.G.K1.description: h. Pitot-static, vacuum/pressure, and associated flight instruments

PA.I.G.K2.description: Indications of and procedures for managing system abnormalities or failures. Risk

PA.I.G.R1.description: Detection of system malfunctions or failures.

PA.I.G.R3.description: Monitoring and management of automated systems.

PA.I.G.S1.description: Operate at least three of the systems listed in K1a through K1l appropriately.

tasks.name: Human Factors
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with personal health, flight physiology, and aeromedical and human factors related to safety of flight.

PA.I.H.K1.description: Symptoms, recognition, causes, effects, and corrective actions associated with aeromedical and physiological issues, including:
c. Middle ear and sinus problems
l. Dissolved nitrogen in the bloodstream after scuba dives

PA.I.H.K2.description: Regulations regarding use of alcohol and drugs.

PA.I.H.K3.description: Effects of alcohol, drugs, and over-the-counter medications.

PA.I.H.K4.description: Aeronautical Decision-Making (ADM) to include using Crew Resource Management (CRM) or Single- Pilot Resource Management (SRM), as appropriate. Risk

PA.I.H.R3.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.I.H.S1.description: Associate the symptoms and effects for at least three of the conditions listed in K1a through K1l with the cause(s) and corrective action(s).

PA.I.H.S2.description: Perform self-assessment, including fitness for flight and personal minimums, for actual flight or a scenario given by the evaluator.

tasks.name: Water and Seaplane Characteristics, Seaplane Bases, Maritime Rules, and Aids to Marine
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with water and seaplane characteristics, seaplane bases, maritime rules, and aids to marine navigation.

PA.I.I.K1.description: The characteristics of a water surface as affected by features, such as:
d. Direction and strength of water current
e. Floating and partially submerged debris
h. Other characteristics specific to the area
i. Direction and height of waves

PA.I.I.K2.description: Float and hull construction, and its effect on seaplane performance.

PA.I.I.K3.description: Causes of porpoising and skipping, and the pilot action needed to prevent or correct these occurrences.

PA.I.I.K4.description: How to locate and identify seaplane bases on charts or in directories.

PA.I.I.K6.description: Right-of-way, steering, and sailing rules pertinent to seaplane operation.

PA.I.I.K7.description: Marine navigation aids, such as buoys, beacons, lights, sound signals, and range markers.

PA.I.I.R3.description: Right-of-way and sailing rules pertinent to seaplane operations.

PA.I.I.R4.description: Limited services and assistance available at seaplane bases.

PA.I.I.S1.description: Assess the water surface characteristics for the proposed flight.

PA.I.I.S2.description: Identify restrictions at local seaplane bases.

PA.I.I.S4.description: Describe correct right-of-way, steering, and sailing operations.

PA.I.I.S5.description: Explain how float and hull construction can affect seaplane performance.

PA.I.I.S6.description: Describe how to correct for porpoising and skipping.

tasks.name: Preflight Assessment
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with preparation for safe flight.

PA.II.A.K2.description: Determining that the airplane to be used is appropriate and airworthy.

PA.II.A.K3.description: a. Which items should be inspected
b. The reasons for checking each item
c. How to detect possible defects

PA.II.A.K4.description: Environmental factors, including weather, terrain, route selection, and obstructions. Risk

PA.II.A.R3.description: Environment (e.g., weather, airports, airspace, terrain, obstacles).

PA.II.A.S1.description: Inspect the airplane with reference to an appropriate checklist.

PA.II.A.S2.description: Verify the airplane is in condition for safe flight and conforms to its type design.

PA.II.A.S4.description: Continue to assess the environment for safe flight.

tasks.name: Flight Deck Management
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with flight deck management practices.
note: See Appendix 2: Safety of Flight.

PA.II.B.K1.description: Passenger briefing requirements, including operation and required use of safety restraint systems.

PA.II.B.K3.description: Requirements for current and appropriate navigation data.

PA.II.B.R1.description: Use of systems or equipment, including automation and portable electronic devices.

PA.II.B.S1.description: Secure all items in the aircraft.

PA.II.B.S2.description: Conduct an appropriate passenger briefing, including identifying the pilot-in-command (PIC), use of safety belts, shoulder harnesses, doors, passenger conduct, sterile aircraft, propeller blade avoidance, and emergency procedures.

PA.II.B.S3.description: Properly program and manage the aircraft’s automation, as applicable.

PA.II.B.S4.description: Appropriately manage risks by utilizing ADM, including SRM/CRM.

tasks.name: Engine Starting
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with recommended engine starting procedures.

PA.II.C.K2.description: Starting the engine(s) by use of external power.

PA.II.C.K4.description: Conditions leading to and procedures for an aborted start. Risk

PA.II.C.S1.description: Position the airplane properly considering structures, other aircraft, wind, and the safety of nearby persons and property.

tasks.name: Taxiing (ASEL, AMEL)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with taxi operations, including runway incursion avoidance.

PA.II.D.K1.description: Current airport aeronautical references and information resources such as the Chart Supplement, airport diagram, and Notices to Air Missions (NOTAMs).

PA.II.D.K6.description: a. Appropriate flight deck activities prior to taxi, including route planning and identifying the location of Hot Spots
b. Radio communications at towered and nontowered airports
e. Low visibility taxi operations Risk

PA.II.D.R2.description: Confirmation or expectation bias as related to taxi instructions.

PA.II.D.R3.description: A taxi route or departure runway change.

PA.II.D.S1.description: Receive and correctly read back clearances/instructions, if applicable.

PA.II.D.S2.description: Use an airport diagram or taxi chart during taxi, if published, and maintain situational awareness.

PA.II.D.S3.description: Position the flight controls for the existing wind, if applicable.

PA.II.D.S5.description: Perform a brake check immediately after the airplane begins moving.

PA.II.D.S6.description: Maintain positive control of the airplane during ground operations by controlling direction and speed without excessive use of brakes.

PA.II.D.S7.description: Comply with airport/taxiway markings, signals, and air traffic control (ATC) clearances and instructions.

PA.II.D.S8.description: Position the airplane properly relative to hold lines.

tasks.name: Taxiing and Sailing (ASES, AMES)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with taxiing and sailing operations, including runway incursion avoidance.

PA.II.E.K1.description: Airport information resources, including Chart Supplements, airport diagram, and appropriate references.

PA.II.E.K3.description: Airport/seaplane base markings, signs, and lights.

PA.II.E.K6.description: a. Appropriate flight deck activities during taxiing or sailing
b. Radio communications at towered and nontowered seaplane bases Risk

PA.II.E.R3.description: Low visibility taxi and sailing operations.

PA.II.E.R5.description: Confirmation or expectation bias as related to taxi instructions.

PA.II.E.S1.description: Receive and correctly read back clearances/instructions, if applicable.

PA.II.E.S2.description: Use an appropriate airport diagram or taxi chart, if published.

PA.II.E.S3.description: Comply with seaplane base/airport/taxiway markings, signals, and signs.

PA.II.E.S4.description: Depart the dock/mooring buoy or beach/ramp in a safe manner, considering wind, current, traffic, and hazards.

PA.II.E.S6.description: Position the flight controls, flaps, doors, water rudders, and power correctly for the existing conditions to follow the desired course while sailing and to prevent or correct for porpoising and skipping during step taxi.

PA.II.E.S7.description: Exhibit procedures for steering and maneuvering while maintaining proper situational awareness and desired orientation, path, and position while taxiing using idle, plow, or step taxi technique, as appropriate.

PA.II.E.S8.description: Plan and follow the most favorable taxi or sailing course for current conditions.

PA.II.E.S9.description: Abide by right-of-way rules, maintain positive airplane control, proper speed, and separation between other aircraft, vessels, and persons.

PA.II.E.S10.description: Comply with applicable taxi elements in Task D if the practical test is conducted in an amphibious airplane.

tasks.name: Before Takeoff Check
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with before takeoff check.

PA.II.F.K1.description: Purpose of before takeoff checklist items, including:
a. Reasons for checking each item
c. Ensuring the aircraft is in safe operating condition as recommended by the manufacturer Risk

PA.II.F.R1.description: Division of attention while conducting before takeoff checks.

PA.II.F.R2.description: Unexpected runway changes by air traffic control (ATC).

PA.II.F.R4.description: Potential powerplant failure during takeoff or other malfunction considering operational factors such as airplane characteristics, runway/takeoff path length, surface conditions, environmental conditions, and obstructions.

PA.II.F.S3.description: Position the airplane appropriately considering wind direction and the presence of any aircraft, vessels, or buildings as applicable.

PA.II.F.S4.description: Divide attention inside and outside the flight deck.

PA.II.F.S5.description: Verify that engine parameters and airplane configuration are suitable.

tasks.name: Communications, Light Signals, and Runway Lighting Systems
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with normal and emergency radio communications, air traffic control (ATC) light signals, and runway lighting systems.

PA.III.A.K1.description: How to obtain appropriate radio frequencies.

PA.III.A.K2.description: Proper radio communication procedures and air traffic control (ATC) phraseology.

PA.III.A.K6.description: Equipment issues that could cause loss of communication.

PA.III.A.K8.description: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) accident/incident reporting.

PA.III.A.R2.description: Deciding if and when to declare an emergency.

PA.III.A.S2.description: Transmit using standard phraseology and procedures as specified in the Aeronautical Information Manual (AIM) and Pilot/Controller Glossary.

PA.III.A.S3.description: Acknowledge radio communications and comply with ATC instructions or as directed by the evaluator.

tasks.name: Traffic Patterns
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with traffic patterns.

PA.III.B.K2.description: Traffic pattern selection for the current conditions.

PA.III.B.K4.description: Use of automated weather and airport information. Risk

PA.III.B.R2.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.III.B.S1.description: Identify and interpret airport/seaplane base runways, taxiways, markings, signs, and lighting.

PA.III.B.S2.description: Comply with recommended traffic pattern procedures.

PA.III.B.S3.description: Correct for wind drift to maintain the proper ground track.

PA.III.B.S4.description: Maintain orientation with the runway/landing area in use.

PA.III.B.S5.description: Maintain traffic pattern altitude, ±100 feet, and the appropriate airspeed, ±10 knots.

PA.III.B.S6.description: Maintain situational awareness and proper spacing from other aircraft in the traffic pattern.

tasks.name: Normal Takeoff and Climb
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with normal takeoff, climb operations, and rejected takeoff procedures.
note: If a crosswind condition does not exist, the applicant’s knowledge of crosswind elements must be evaluated through oral testing.

PA.IV.A.K1.description: Effects of atmospheric conditions, including wind, on takeoff and climb performance.

PA.IV.A.K2.description: Best angle of climb speed (X ) and best rate of climb speed YV ).

PA.IV.A.R1.description: Selection of runway or takeoff path based on aircraft performance and limitations, available distance, and wind.

PA.IV.A.R3.description: b. Potential engine failure in takeoff/climb phase of flight

PA.IV.A.R5.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.IV.A.R6.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.IV.A.S3.description: Verify assigned/correct runway or takeoff path.

PA.IV.A.S4.description: Determine wind direction with or without visible wind direction indicators.

PA.IV.A.S5.description: Position the flight controls for the existing wind, if applicable.

PA.IV.A.S6.description: Clear the area, taxi into takeoff position, and align the airplane on the runway centerline (ASEL, AMEL) or takeoff path (ASES, AMES).
a. Retract the water rudders, as appropriate (ASES, AMES)

PA.IV.A.S7.description: Advance the throttle smoothly to takeoff power and confirm proper engine and flight instrument indications prior to rotation.
a. Establish and maintain the most efficient planing/lift-off attitude, and correct for porpoising or skipping (ASES, AMES)

PA.IV.A.S8.description: Avoid excessive water spray on the propeller(s) (ASES, AMES).

PA.IV.A.S9.description: Rotate and lift off at the recommended airspeed and accelerate to V . Y

PA.IV.A.S11.description: Establish a pitch attitude to maintain the manufacturer’s recommended speed or V ,Y+10/-5 knots.

PA.IV.A.S12.description: Configure the airplane in accordance with manufacturer’s guidance.

PA.IV.A.S13.description: Maintain V Y10/-5 knots to a safe maneuvering altitude.

PA.IV.A.S14.description: Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout takeoff and climb.

PA.IV.A.S15.description: Comply with noise abatement procedures, as applicable.

tasks.name: Normal Approach and Landing
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with normal approach and landing with emphasis on proper use and coordination of flight controls.
note: If a crosswind condition does not exist, the applicant’s knowledge of crosswind elements must be evaluated through oral testing.

PA.IV.B.K1.description: A stabilized approach, including energy management concepts.

PA.IV.B.K2.description: Effects of atmospheric conditions, including wind, on approach and landing performance.

PA.IV.B.K3.description: Wind correction techniques on approach and landing. Risk

PA.IV.B.R1.description: Selection of runway/landing surface, approach path, and touchdown area based on pilot capability, aircraft performance and limitations, available distance, and wind.

PA.IV.B.R3.description: b. Land and hold short operations (LAHSO)

PA.IV.B.R5.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.IV.B.R6.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.IV.B.S3.description: Ensure the airplane is aligned with the correct/assigned runway or landing surface.

PA.IV.B.S4.description: Scan the runway or landing surface and adjoining area for traffic and obstructions.

PA.IV.B.S5.description: Select and aim for a suitable touchdown point considering the wind conditions, landing surface, and obstructions.

PA.IV.B.S6.description: Establish the recommended approach and landing configuration, airspeed, and trim, and adjust pitch attitude and power as required to maintain a stabilized approach.

PA.IV.B.S7.description: Maintain manufacturer’s published approach airspeed or in its absence not more than 1.3 times the stalling speed or the minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration (VSO, +10/-5 knots with gust factor applied.

PA.IV.B.S8.description: Maintain directional control and appropriate crosswind correction throughout the approach and landing.

PA.IV.B.S9.description: Make smooth, timely, and correct control application during round out and touchdown.

PA.IV.B.S10.description: Touch down at a proper pitch attitude, within 400 feet beyond or on the specified point, with no side drift, and with the airplane’s longitudinal axis aligned with and over the runway center/landing path.

PA.IV.B.S11.description: Execute a timely go-around if the approach cannot be made within the tolerances specified above or for any other condition that may result in an unsafe approach or landing.

PA.IV.B.S12.description: Use runway incursion avoidance procedures, if applicable.

tasks.name: Soft-Field Takeoff and Climb (ASEL)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with soft-field takeoff, climb operations, and rejected takeoff procedures.

PA.IV.C.K1.description: Effects of atmospheric conditions, including wind, on takeoff and climb performance.

PA.IV.C.K2.description: Best angle of climb speed (V X and best rate of climb speed (V Y.

PA.IV.C.K5.description: Importance of weight transfer from wheels to wings.

PA.IV.C.R1.description: Selection of runway based on pilot capability, airplane performance and limitations, available distance, and wind.

PA.IV.C.R3.description: b. Potential engine failure in takeoff/climb phase of flight

PA.IV.C.R5.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.IV.C.R6.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.IV.C.S4.description: Determine wind direction with or without visible wind direction indicators.

PA.IV.C.S5.description: Position the flight controls for the existing wind, if applicable.

PA.IV.C.S6.description: Clear the area, maintain necessary flight control inputs, taxi into takeoff position and align the airplane on the runway centerline without stopping, while advancing the throttle smoothly to takeoff power.

PA.IV.C.S7.description: Confirm takeoff power and proper engine and flight instrument indications.

PA.IV.C.S8.description: Establish and maintain a pitch attitude that transfers the weight of the airplane from the wheels to the wings as rapidly as possible.

PA.IV.C.S9.description: Lift off at the lowest possible airspeed and remain in ground effect while accelerating to V or V , as appropriate.                                                                             X     Y

PA.IV.C.S10.description: Establish a pitch attitude forXV or Y , as appropriate, and maintain selected airspeed +10/-5 knots during the climb.

PA.IV.C.S11.description: Configure the airplane after a positive rate of climb has been verified or in accordance with airplane manufacturer’s instructions.

PA.IV.C.S12.description: Maintain VXor V Y as appropriate, +10/-5 knots to a safe maneuvering altitude.

PA.IV.C.S13.description: Maintain directional control and proper wind-drift correction throughout takeoff and climb.

PA.IV.C.S14.description: Comply with noise abatement procedures, as applicable.

tasks.name: Soft-Field Approach and Landing (ASEL)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with soft-field approach and landing with emphasis on proper use and coordination of flight controls.

PA.IV.D.K1.description: A stabilized approach, including energy management concepts.

PA.IV.D.K2.description: Effects of atmospheric conditions, including wind, on approach and landing performance.

PA.IV.D.K3.description: Wind correction techniques on approach and landing. Risk

PA.IV.D.R1.description: Selection of runway based on pilot capability, airplane performance and limitations, available distance, and wind.

PA.IV.D.R3.description: b. Land and hold short operations (LAHSO)

PA.IV.D.R5.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.IV.D.R6.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.IV.D.S3.description: Ensure the airplane is aligned with the correct/assigned runway.

PA.IV.D.S4.description: Scan the landing runway and adjoining area for traffic and obstructions.

PA.IV.D.S5.description: Select and aim for a suitable touchdown point considering the wind conditions, landing surface, and obstructions.

PA.IV.D.S6.description: Establish the recommended approach and landing configuration, airspeed, and trim, and adjust pitch attitude and power as required to maintain a stabilized approach.

PA.IV.D.S7.description: Maintain manufacturer’s published approach airspeed or in its absence not more than 1.3 V , SO0/-5 knots with gust factor applied.

PA.IV.D.S8.description: Maintain directional control and appropriate crosswind correction throughout the approach and landing.

PA.IV.D.S9.description: Make smooth, timely, and correct control inputs during the round out and touchdown, and, for tricycle gear airplanes, keep the nose wheel off the surface until loss of elevator effectiveness.

PA.IV.D.S10.description: Touch down at a proper pitch attitude with minimum sink rate, no side drift, and with the airplane’s longitudinal axis aligned with the center of the runway.

PA.IV.D.S11.description: Maintain elevator as recommended by manufacturer during rollout and exit the “soft” area at a speed that would preclude sinking into the surface.

PA.IV.D.S12.description: Execute a timely go-around if the approach cannot be made within the tolerances specified above or for any other condition that may result in an unsafe approach or landing.

PA.IV.D.S13.description: Maintain proper position of the flight controls and sufficient speed to taxi while on the soft surface.

tasks.name: Short-Field Takeoff and Maximum Performance Climb (ASEL, AMEL)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with short-field takeoff, maximum performance climb operations, and rejected takeoff procedures.

PA.X.B.R3.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.X.B.S1.description: Configure the airplane in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations, in the absence of the manufacturer’s recommendations, then at safe single-engine speed (V    SSE/VYSE, as appropriate, and:
c. Cowl flaps set for takeoff
e. Propellers set for high revolutions per minute (rpm)
f. Power on critical engine reduced to idle and propeller windmilling
g. Power on operating engine set to takeoff or maximum available power

PA.X.B.S2.description: Establish a single-engine climb attitude with the airspeed at approximately 10 knots above V SSE.

PA.X.B.S3.description: Establish a bank angle not to exceed 5° toward the operating engine, as required for best performance and controllability.

PA.X.B.S4.description: Increase the pitch attitude slowly to reduce the airspeed at approximately 1 knot per second while applying increased rudder pressure as needed to maintain directional control.

PA.X.B.S5.description: Recognize and recover at the first indication of loss of directional control, stall warning, or buffet.

PA.X.B.S6.description: Recover promptly by simultaneously reducing power sufficiently on the operating engine, decreasing the angle of attack as necessary to regain airspeed and directional control, and without adding power on the simulated failed engine.

PA.X.B.S8.description: Advance power smoothly on the operating engine and accelerate to V    SSE/VYSE as appropriate, +10/-5 knots during recovery.

tasks.name: One Engine Inoperative (Simulated) (solely by Reference to Instruments) During Straight-and-
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with flight solely by reference to instruments with one engine inoperative.
note: See Appendix 2: Safety of Flight and Appendix 3: Aircraft, Equipment, and Operational Requirements & Limitations for information related to this Task.

PA.X.C.K1.description: Procedures used if engine failure occurs during straight-and-level flight and turns while on instruments. Risk

PA.X.C.R2.description: Inability to climb or maintain altitude with an inoperative engine.

PA.X.C.R3.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.X.C.R4.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.X.C.S1.description: Promptly recognize an engine failure and maintain positive aircraft control.

PA.X.C.S2.description: Set the engine controls, reduce drag, identify and verify the inoperative engine, and simulate feathering of the propeller on the inoperative engine (evaluator should then establish zero thrust on the inoperative engine).

PA.X.C.S3.description: Establish the best engine-inoperative airspeed and trim the airplane.

PA.X.C.S4.description: Use flight controls in the proper combination as recommended by the manufacturer, or as required to maintain best performance, and trim as required.

PA.X.C.S5.description: Verify the prescribed checklist procedures used for securing the inoperative engine.

PA.X.C.S6.description: Attempt to determine and resolve the reason for the engine failure.

PA.X.C.S7.description: Monitor engine functions and make necessary adjustments.

PA.X.C.S8.description: Maintain the specified altitude ±100 feet or minimum sink rate if applicable, airspeed ±10 knots, and the specified heading ±10°.

PA.X.C.S9.description: Assess the aircraft’s performance capability and decide an appropriate action to ensure a safe landing.

PA.X.C.S10.description: Avoid loss of airplane control or attempted flight contrary to the engine-inoperative operating limitations of the airplane.

PA.X.C.S11.description: Use single-pilot resource management (SRM) or crew resource management (CRM), as appropriate.

tasks.name: Instrument Approach and Landing with an Inoperative Engine (Simulated) (AMEL, AMES)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with executing a published instrument approach solely by reference to instruments with one engine inoperative.
note: See Appendix 2: Safety of Flight and Appendix 3: Aircraft, Equipment, and Operational Requirements & Limitations for information related to this Task.
For non-amphibious seaplanes, this task applies only when the applicant has immediate access to an instrument approach to a waterway.

PA.X.D.K1.description: Instrument approach procedures with one engine inoperative. Risk

PA.X.D.R1.description: Potential engine failure during approach and landing.

PA.X.D.R4.description: Low altitude maneuvering, including stall, spin, or controlled flight into terrain (CFIT).

PA.X.D.R5.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.X.D.R6.description: Performing a go-around/rejected landing with an engine failure.

PA.X.D.S1.description: Promptly recognize an engine failure and maintain positive aircraft control.

PA.X.D.S2.description: Set the engine controls, reduce drag, identify and verify the inoperative engine, and simulate feathering of the propeller on the inoperative engine (evaluator should then establish zero thrust on the inoperative engine).

PA.X.D.S3.description: Use flight controls in the proper combination as recommended by the manufacturer, or as required to maintain best performance, and trim as required.

PA.X.D.S4.description: Follow the manufacturer’s recommended emergency procedures and complete the appropriate checklist.

PA.X.D.S5.description: Monitor the operating engine and aircraft systems and make adjustments as necessary.

PA.X.D.S6.description: Request and follow an actual or a simulated air traffic control (ATC) clearance for an instrument approach.

PA.X.D.S7.description: Maintain altitude ±100 feet or minimum sink rate if applicable, airspeed ±10 knots, and selected heading ±10°.

PA.X.D.S8.description: Establish a rate of descent that ensures arrival at the minimum descent altitude (MDA) or decision altitude (DA)/decision height (DH) with the airplane in a position from which a descent to a landing on the intended runway or landing path can be made, either straight in or circling as appropriate.

PA.X.D.S9.description: On final approach segment, maintain vertical (as applicable) and lateral guidance within ¾-scale deflection.

PA.X.D.S10.description: Avoid loss of airplane control or attempted flight contrary to the operating limitations of the airplane.

PA.X.D.S11.description: Comply with the published criteria for the aircraft approach category if circling.

tasks.name: Night Operations
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge and risk management associated with night operations.
note: For applicants that reside in Alaska, refer to 14 CFR part 61, section 61.110.

PA.XI.A.K1.description: Physiological aspects of vision related to night flying.

PA.XI.A.K2.description: Lighting systems identifying airports, runways, taxiways and obstructions, as well as pilot controlled lighting.

PA.XI.A.K3.description: Airplane equipment and lighting requirements for night operations.

PA.XI.A.K4.description: Personal equipment essential for night flight.

PA.XI.A.K5.description: Night orientation, navigation, chart reading techniques and methods for maintaining night vision effectiveness.

PA.XI.A.K7.description: Interpretation of traffic position and direction based solely on position lights.

PA.XI.A.R2.description: Distractions, task prioritization, loss of situational awareness, or disorientation.

PA.XI.A.R3.description: Effect of visual illusions and night adaptation during all phases of night flying.

PA.XI.A.R6.description: Weather considerations specific to night operations.

tasks.name: After Landing, Parking, and Securing (ASEL, AMEL)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with after landing, parking, and securing procedures.

PA.XII.A.K1.description: Airplane shutdown, securing, and postflight inspection.

PA.XII.A.R4.description: Disembarking passengers safely on the ramp and monitoring passenger movement while on the ramp.

PA.XII.A.S2.description: Park in an appropriate area, considering the safety of nearby persons and property.

PA.XII.A.S4.description: Conduct a postflight inspection and document discrepancies and servicing requirements, if any.

tasks.name: Seaplane Post-Landing Procedures (ASES, AMES)
tasks.objective: To determine the applicant exhibits satisfactory knowledge, risk management, and skills associated with anchoring, docking, mooring, and ramping/beaching.
note: The evaluator must select at least one after-landing procedure (anchoring, docking and mooring, or ramping/beaching).

PA.XII.B.K5.description: Postflight inspection, recording of in-flight/postflight discrepancies. Risk

PA.XII.B.R3.description: Seaplane base specific security procedures, if applicable.

PA.XII.B.R4.description: Disembarking passengers safely on the ramp and monitoring passenger movement while on the ramp.

PA.XII.B.S1.description: If anchoring, select a suitable area considering seaplane movement, water depth, tide, wind, and weather changes. Use an adequate number of anchors and lines of sufficient strength and length to ensure the seaplane’s security.

PA.XII.B.S2.description: If not anchoring, approach the dock/mooring buoy or beach/ramp in the proper direction and at a safe speed, considering water depth, tide, current, and wind.

PA.XII.B.S4.description: Conduct a postflight inspection and document discrepancies and servicing requirements, if any.

PA.XII.B.S5.description: Secure the seaplane considering the effect of wind, waves, and changes in water level, or comply with applicable after landing, parking, and securing procedures if operating an amphibious airplane on land.
